properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall possible this afternoon and evening as a frontal system approaches with modified arctic air in place for the south coast. A frontal system will arrive over the south coast this afternoon. The front combined with the modified arctic air in place will give the potential to produce accumulating snow for neighbourhoods and roadways above 200 metres, including the Malahat Summit and Port Alberni Summit on Hwy 4. Wet snow is possible down to sea level on the mainland side where a cool easterly wind may keep surface temperatures just above the freezing mark. Snowfall amounts of up to 5 cm are possible mainly over higher terrain. The front will move out of the region overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T04:46:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T12:47:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3486374989.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, Inland Vancouver Island, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues tonight. Periods of freezing rain will taper off from south to north through Monday morning. Ice accumulations of 5 to 10 mm are possible in some locations. Snow and ice pellet amounts of 5 to 10 cm will also be a possibility in the Fort Severn area. Surfaces may become icy and slippery. ### Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-09T19:52:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T03:53:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3332803301.2020
Area: Fort Severn, Peawanuck, Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By Resort Village Of Thode
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Resort Village of Thode. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the the Resort Village of Thode water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-11-13T17:00:00-06:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall possible this afternoon and evening as a frontal system approaches with modified arctic air in place for the south coast. A frontal system will arrive over the south coast this afternoon. The front combined with the modified arctic air in place will give the potential to produce accumulating snow for neighbourhoods and roadways above 200 metres, including the Malahat Summit and Port Alberni Summit on Hwy 4. Wet snow is possible down to sea level on the mainland side where a cool easterly wind may keep surface temperatures just above the freezing mark. Snowfall amounts of up to 5 cm are possible mainly over higher terrain. The front will move out of the region overnight. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T04:46:20-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts 15 to 25 cm are forecast tonight and early Monday. A deep low will move across Yukon tonight then into Northwest Territories Monday. Snow in advance of the system has reached the area this afternoon and will continue through Monday morning. The snow will end later Monday as the system departs. A ridge of high pressure building quickly behind the system will bring gusty winds and local blowing snow on Monday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-09T19:24:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T03:25:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0423396772.2020
Area: Dawson, Mayo
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An intense weather system is moving through the Arctic Islands. Strengthening southeasterly winds combined with falling snow are expected to produce blizzard conditions by this afternoon. The blizzard conditions will persist through Monday night before coming to an end late Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T07:30:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T15:31:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2370075148.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow will continue into this morning before easing to a mix of wet flurries and rain showers. Upwards of 15 cm total accumulations can be expected, ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T01:07:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T14:25:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1688775006.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A low pressure system crossing central Yukon this morning will give 5 to 10 cm of new snow to the region today. Strong northwest winds of 40 km/h gusting to 60 will also develop this morning in the wake of the low. The combination of snow and blowing snow will cause poor visibilities at times. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T03:32:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T11:33:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0417470651.2020
Area: Beaver Creek, Pelly - Carmacks
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A potent winter storm is bringing heavy snow, wind, and freezing rain to parts of Saskatchewan and Manitoba. A powerful Colorado Low will move through the Prairies tonight. Moderate to heavy snow will spread northeastwards through Saskatchewan tonight and continue on Monday across Manitoba. Snowfall totals as high as 30 to 50 cm are expected. Moderate northerly winds will develop and produce periods of reduced visibility in blowing snow overnight. Some regions will also see a mix of snow and freezing rain; consult local forecasts for more details on the location and timing. Conditions will gradually improve from southwest to northeast later overnight through Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-09T19:59:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T06:16:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0477871609.2020
Area: Westgate Red Deer Lake and Barrows, Porcupine Prov. Forest, R.M. of Mountain including Mafeking and Birch River, Pelican Rapids and Shoal River First Nations, Mun. of Swan Valley West incl. Benito, Mun. of Minitonas-Bowsman incl. Renwer, Duck Mountain Prov. Park and Prov. Forest, R.M. of Mountain including Cowan and Camperville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep low is moving across central Yukon early this morning. It will be followed by a rapidly building ridge of high pressure from the Beaufort Sea. Consequently, east winds of 80 km/h with gusts up to 100 are occurring near the Richardson Mountains. The winds combined with freshly fallen snow will give blizzard conditions to the area. Conditions are forecast to improve this afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T03:36:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T11:37:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4000420938.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strengthening northwesterly winds are expected to produce blizzard conditions tonight into Tuesday morning. Conditions will be worse in exposed areas such as over the Amundsen Gulf and Dolphin Strait. Visibility will improve through the day Tuesday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T09:34:26-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A potent winter storm continues to bring heavy snow to parts of east-central Saskatchewan and northern Manitoba The bulk of the snow associated with a Colorado Low moving through the Prairies fell yesterday, but further accumulations of 2 to 5 cm is expected this morning in parts of east-central Saskatchewan and northern Manitoba. Along with the snow, northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h may create reduced visibilities in blowing snow in open areas. As well, over northern Manitoba, this morning, some regions may see freezing rain mixed in with the snow. Conditions will gradually improve later this morning and through the afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-09T19:59:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T10:19:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0943572409.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. Wet snow developing this afternoon mainly over higher terrain. A Pacific frontal system approaching from the northwest will arrive on the south coast later today bringing wet snow or rain to Metro Vancouver this afternoon. The precipitation will last through this evening and then end overnight as the system moves to the south. Snowfall amounts will vary considerably depending on elevation. Accumulations will range from a trace to 2 cm at sea level, near 5 cm at 150 metres above sea level and up to 10 cm for the highest neighbourhoods. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T04:35:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T12:36:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2876098361.2020
Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A strong frontal system moving in from the Pacific will move over central British Columbia and bring widespread snow for today. Snow will begin early this morning and continue throughout the day. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 cm can be expected in the Stuart-Nechako, Prince George and Cariboo-North regions before the system departs further into southeastern British Columbia this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T04:58:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-09T12:59:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1100575279.2020
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Stuart - Nechako, Prince George
